sub_topic: Calculating the magnetic moment of inorganic compounds.
message_1: Calculate the magnetic moment of a cobalt (II) ion, Co2+ in an octahedral field with a ligand field strength of 800 cm-1.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic moment of a cobalt (II) ion (Co2+) in an octahedral field, we need to determine the electron configuration of the ion and then find the number of unpaired electrons. Finally, we will use the spin-only formula to calculate the magnetic moment.

Cobalt has an atomic number of 27, so its ground state electron configuration is [Ar] 4s² 3d⁷. When cobalt loses two electrons to form the Co²⁺ ion, its electron configuration becomes [Ar] 3d⁷ → [Ar] 3d⁵.

In an octahedral field, the five d orbitals split into two energy levels: the lower-energy t₂g orbitals (dxy, dyz, and dxz) and the higher-energy e_g orbitals (dz² and dx²-y²). The ligand field strength (800 cm⁻¹) does not affect the electron configuration in this case, as it only influences the energy gap between the t₂g and e_g orbitals.

The electron configuration of Co²⁺ in an octahedral field is:

t₂g ↑↓ ↑↓ ↑ (3 electrons in t₂g orbitals)
e_g ↑↑ (2 electrons in e_g orbitals)

There are a total of 5 unpaired electrons in the Co²⁺ ion.

Now, we can use the spin-only formula to calculate the magnetic moment (μ):

μ = √(n(n+2)) μ_B

where n is the number of unpaired electrons and μ_B is the Bohr magneton (approximately 9.27 × 10⁻²⁴ Am²).

μ = √(5(5+2)) μ_B
μ = √(5(7)) μ_B
μ = √35 μ_B

The magnetic moment of the Co²⁺ ion in an octahedral field is approximately √35 μ_B.
